A highly efficient bi-functional zeolite catalyst for low temperature catalytic cracking of n-octane to produce propylene: Joint contribution of nanogold and dealumination Lei Wu Conceptualization Methodology Software Validation Investigation Writing – original draft a Caixia Qi Conceptualization Validation Resources Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ 1 Xun Sun Formal analysis a Huijuan Su Data curation Supervision a Libo Sun Formal analysis: Data curation a Lijun Zhao Supervision a Fengshou Xiao b a Yantai Key Laboratory of Gold Catalysis and Engineering, Shandong Applied Research Center of Nanogold Technology (Au-SDARC), School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, China Yantai Key Laboratory of Gold Catalysis and Engineering, Shandong Applied Research Center of Nanogold Technology (Au-SDARC), School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University Yantai 264005 China Yantai Key Laboratory of Gold Catalysis and Engineering, Shandong Applied Research Center of Nanogold Technology (Au-SDARC), School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, China b Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, China Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310028 China Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Homepage: http://www.qicxlab.com With respect to catalysis, the pursuit of low reaction temperatures has received continuous efforts for developing energy efficient and environmentally friendly processes. In this study, the significant promotion in the catalytic cracking performance of n-octane at low temperatures of 260–460 °C over Au/ZSM-5 catalysts was obtained via the joint contribution of dealumination and Au species. A 63.5% propylene selectivity and 100% n-octane conversion were obtained over the optimized catalyst at 410 °C. The higher propylene yield was attributed to an increase in the concentration of Brønsted acids and a decrease in that of Lewis acids, as well as synergy between acid sites and Au species. The positive effect of Au species during dehydrogenation at lower temperatures was verified, and electron transfer from Au to the zeolite framework was proposed. Graphical Abstract The significant promotion in the catalytic cracking performance of n-octane at 260 ∼ 460 °C over Au/ZSM-5 catalysts was obtained via joint contribution of dealumination and Au species, resulting a highest PO yield reported so far, i.e., 100% n-octane conversion and 62.6% of propylene selectivity of over the optimized catalyst at 410 °C. Moreover, the modified catalyst exhibited similar performance to the parent ZSM-5 at temperature lower than 150 °C, showing vast benefit for energy saving and environment friendly in petroleum industry process. ga1 Keywords Au/ZSM-5 Dealumination Catalytic cracking Propylene N-Octane Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction At present, the total consumption of fossil energy such as oil, natural gas, and coal accounts for more than 80% of primary energy. Crude oil still accounts for the highest proportion of primary energy. Petrochemical processes consume large amounts of energy and are the main source of greenhouse gas emissions [1]. Fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) is one of the most important carbon emission sources in traditional oil refineries. With the continuous promotion of global electrification and "carbon neutrality" policies, the transformation of energy structure and improvements in energy efficiency will be the only way to achieve carbon neutrality. Optimizing systems, processes, and equipment, saving energy, and improving energy efficiency are the primary ways for reducing carbon emissions. As an important raw material for organic synthesis, the global demand for propylene continues to grow. Fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) plays a more important role in propylene production than steam cracking due to the higher ratio of propylene to ethane and lower energy consumption [2–8]. As a catalyst or additive in the FCC process, modified ZSM-5 that is currently available has been used for propylene production, but the working temperatures are quite high (> 510 °C). However, a lower temperature limits the production of propylene [9–11]. Many research teams have used different reaction systems to demonstrate the advantages of Au catalysts, which show excellent low-temperature catalytic activity and high product selectivity [12–18] including our own work [19,20]. Prof. Haruta oxidized CO over TiO2, α-Fe2O3, and Co3O4 at temperatures as low as − 70 °C [21] and performed the epoxidation of propylene over Au/TiO2 with a propylene oxide selectivity greater than 90% [22]. We have previously reported that the catalytic cracking of light diesel oil can work well at a lower temperature of 460 °C with improved feed conversion, micro-reactivity, and propylene selectivity by introducing small amounts of Au nanoparticles into ZSM-5 [23]. We found that Au0 rather than Auδ+ promoted the production of propylene and the catalytic cracking activity [24]. Guo et al. [25] also reported that a series of aluminosilicate molecular sieve-supported gold catalysts exhibited high activity at a low reaction temperature for the aromatization, isomerization, alkylation, and catalytic cracking of low-carbon alkanes (C3 −C9). This further supports the potential application of gold nanoparticles in the field of petroleum chemistry, but the intrinsic role of gold nanoparticles is not clear in this typical acid-driven reaction. In the FCC process, alkane cracking is one of the main reactions. The cracking of light hydrocarbons on acidic zeolites mainly follows an acid-catalyzed process involving carbonium ions [26,27]. Sazama et al. [28] investigated the effect of the spatial distance between the acidic centers (Al) of ZSM-5 on the cleavage of 1-butene and found that “single” Al atoms of ZSM-5 contributed to the cleavage of olefins. “Close” Al atoms contributed to oligomerization and hydrogen transfer, which mainly produced aromatic compounds; thus, modulating the microscopic acidity of zeolite is important for catalytic cracking reactions. To transition from “close” Al to “single” Al atoms in ZSM-5 zeolite, a certain degree of dealumination of the zeolite is required. Different dealumination methods and conditions will have different effects on the properties and functions of a particular zeolite. After decades of research and exploration by scientists, zeolite dealumination routes can be broadly divided into (a) thermal treatment and hydrothermal treatment methods at high temperatures [29,30] or (b) chemical dealumination methods [31,32]. The latter include reactions between acids, bases, salts, and zeolite and reactions between inorganic coordination ions (F-), chelating agents (EDTA, ACAC, etc.), and aluminum. Each of these routes has its own advantages and disadvantages. (NH4)2SiF6 was used to dealuminate ZSM-5 zeolite via the hydrolysis of (NH4)2SiF6 as follows [32]: (1) (NH4)2SiF6 → 2NH4 + + SiF6 2- (2) SiF6 2- + 4 H2O → Si(OH)4 + 6 F- + 4 H+ During the reaction, (NH4)2SiF6 is first hydrolyzed to Si(OH)4, and the dissociated F- interacts with the framework Al to produce AlF6 3-. Then, Si(OH)4 is inserted into the Al cavity, thus completing the dealumination and silicon replenishment. Pursuing low reaction temperatures deserves continuous efforts in regard to catalysis for energy efficiency and environmental friendly. The main objective of this work is to further improve the propylene production in the Au/ZSM-5 catalyst system at a low reaction temperature via the cooperation of nanogold and dealumination. Secondly, we attempt to determine the individual role of nanogold and the possible synergetic effects between the nanogold and acidic sites on ZSM-5. The cracking of n-octane was applied as a test feed. The performance of the optimized catalyst at 260 °C and 310 °C was similar to that of the parent ZSM-5 at 410 °C and 460 °C, respectively. Furthermore, at 410 °C, the optimized catalyst achieved 100% n-octane conversion and 63.5% propylene selectivity, which is the highest propylene yield reported so far. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of ZSM-5 catalysts In this work, all chemicals were obtained from commercial suppliers (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and Xiya Reagent) and used without further purification. 2.1.1 Preparation of Au precursors (Au(en)2Cl3) [33,34] Ethylenediamine (0.09 mL) solution was added to 2 mL of 0.1 g/mL HAuCl4 solution dropwise under magnetic stirring and then stirred for 30 min. Then, 14 mL of anhydrous ethanol was added dropwise and stirred for another 30 min. The obtained suspension was separated by centrifugation and washed twice with anhydrous ethanol. Au(en)2Cl3 powder was then obtained by vacuum drying at 40 °C for 12 h. 2.1.2 Dealumination of ZSM-5 zeolite ZSM-5 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 37.3, Tianjin Shenneng Technology Co., Ltd.) was roasted in the air at 550 °C for 4 h to remove the template agent before use. The dealumination of ZSM-5 zeolite was processed as follows: The above-obtained ZSM-5 zeolite (10 g) was placed in 200 mL of deionized water. Then, a certain amount of ammonium hexafluorosilicate solution was added with a ratio of n AHFS: n Al = 1: 1 at 80 °C, followed by stirring for 2 h. The mixture was then cooled to room temperature and washed by centrifugation three times. The resultant solid was dried overnight at 80 °C and finally calcined for 4 h at 550 °C to obtain the dealuminated ZSM-5, namely ZSM-5-F. 2.1.3 Preparation of Au/ZSM-5-F Gold was deposited on ZSM-5-F by an isovolumetric impregnation method. The Au/ZSM-5-F catalysts with different Au loadings were obtained after impregnating the ZSM-F support in a solution of Au(en)2Cl3 for 24 h. The resultant solid was filtered and washed with deionized water, dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. 2.1.4 Exchange of sodium (Na+) and cobalt (Co2+) ions in ZSM-5 catalysts support (1) ZSM-5 (2 g) was dispersed in 200 mL of aqueous NaCl (0.5 mol/L), stirred at 80 °C for 8 h, then washed and dried. The exchange process was repeated three times to obtain Na-ZSM-5. (2) Na-ZSM-5 (1 g) was dispersed in 100 mL of aqueous cobalt nitrate solution (0.05 mol/L). Ion exchange was performed at room temperature for 8 h, then washed, and dried. The procedure was repeated three times to obtain Co-ZSM-5. The specific contents of “Close” Al and “Single” Al atoms in a ZSM-5 sample were calculated by the following equations [35]: (3) [“Single” Al] = [Altotal] − 2 [Comax] (4) [“Close” Al] = 2 [Comax] 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystallographic analysis of the catalysts was carried out using a Shimadzu XRD-6100 powder X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα monochromatic radiation source (λ = 0.154 nm) at a scanning speed of 6°/min at 40 kV and 100 mA. The specific surface areas and pore size distributions of the catalysts were obtained using a Mack 3Flex adsorption analyzer (USA) under a vacuum pressure of 20 mTorr at an operating temperature of − 196 °C. The catalysts were vacuum-degassed at a pretreatment temperature of 200 °C for 8 h prior to testing. Surface area, microporous area, and micropore volume were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation and the t-plot method, respectively. The pore size distribution was obtained by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT). Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES; Agilent 5110) was used to determine the elemental content of the catalysts. Before ICP analysis, the catalysts were added to a mixture of hydrofluoric acid at 80 °C for digestion. The digested solution was then volumetrically determined using a volumetric flask. The distribution of Au nanoparticles in the catalysts was observed on a JEOL TEM-2100 transmission electron microscope (TEM) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) was also carried out to obtain the element mappings of Au, Si, and Al in the Au/ZSM-5-F catalyst. The Au LIII-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were measured at BL14B2, SPring-8 (Hyogo,Japan). NH3-TPD measurements were carried out on a TP-5080 multi-functional adsorption instrument. The catalysts were pretreated at 500 °C for 2 h under a helium stream and then cooled to room temperature. Ammonia was then introduced to the catalyst chamber for 0.5 h and purged with helium for another 0.5 h. Finally, desorbed ammonia was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) when the temperature was raised from room temperature to 700 °C under helium. Pyridine adsorption-infrared (Py-IR) spectra of the catalysts were measured on a Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Nicolet 6700, USA) with a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1 with 32 scans. The catalysts were first purified at 500 °C for 30 min under a high vacuum of 10−5 Pa and then pyridine was adsorbed at room temperature. Finally, the residual adsorbed pyridine was recorded after vacuum desorption at 160, 250, and 350 °C, respectively. Quartz-spring gravimetric adsorption-infrared spectroscopy was adopted to quantitatively determine the concentration of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the catalysts [36,37]. The specific method involved selecting a representative group of Y zeolite samples that contained the basic elements of Si and Al and obtaining their pyridine adsorption-infrared spectra. The absorbance A B and A L of each sample were determined from the characteristic peaks of Brønsted acids and Lewis acids of the sample by using the equation A i = lg(I/I o), where I o and I are the transmittance of the baseline and peak summit of the characteristic peaks, respectively. The total acidity (C) of the samples was determined by the weight of chemically-adsorbed pyridine, as measured by a quartz spring. According to Beale's law of A = KCL, where A is absorbance; K is the absorption coefficient; L is sample the thickness. The absorption coefficients K B of Brønsted acids and K L of Lewis acids in the zeolite samples were obtained by solving multiple sets of standard simultaneous equations based on the non-standard sample quantitative method and the least-squares method. The calculated values of K B and K L are 34.29 and 71.32, respectively, and the ratio of K L/K B is 2.08. Then, the amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acids on a studied catalyst surface were calculated by using K B and K L via the following formulas: (5) C B = KB/KL·AB·C / (KB/KL·AB+AL) (6) C L = AL·C / (KB/KL·AB+AL) where C B and C L are the concentrations of Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites (mmol·g−1), respectively. The 29Si and 27Al MAS NMR spectra were used to determine the Si and Al arrangements and to differentiate Al in different chemical environments in the studied zeolite-based Au catalysts. 29Si and 27Al MAS NMR characterization were performed on a Bruker 400 M solid-state NMR spectrometer with a MAS spin rate of 10 kHz and recovery time of 4 s. A pulsed program was used for acquisition with a pre-scan delay of 6.5 μs and a rotor of 4 mm. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation Catalytic tests were carried out in a small confined fluidized bed reactor at 260–460 °C using 3 g catalyst and 0.94 g feed. The contact time was 70 s. The products were separated through an ice-water bath and analyzed by an on‐line gas chromatogram GC‐920X with a flame ionization detector equipped with an OV‐101 capillary column. The area normalization method was applied to collect the data. The conversion of n-octane and the selectivity of target products were calculated using equations (7) and (8): (7) Conversion = 1 − mol of unreacted n − octane mol of reactant n − octane (8) Selectivity = mol of carbon atom in target product mol of carbon atom in all reactants 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical properties of the modified catalysts To investigate the effect of different modification conditions on the textural structure of ZSM-5, all catalysts were characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. 1a, all catalysts showed characteristic diffraction peaks of ZSM-5 with a typical MFI framework structure at 7.9, 8.8, 23.1, 23.9, and 24.3°, corresponding to the (101), (020), (501), (151), and (303) crystal planes (JCPDS no.: 49–0657) [38], respectively. The peak intensities of the catalysts with Au decreased gradually upon increasing the Au loading, indicating a lower ZSM-5 crystallinity during metal impregnation. The characteristic peaks corresponding to the Au (111) and (200) crystal planes at 2θ = 38.2 and 44.4° were detected, and their intensity increased steadily upon increasing the Au loading, as shown in Fig. 1b, implying the presence of larger Au nanoparticles. Fig. S1 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (a) and pore size distribution curves (b) of the ZSM-5-based catalysts. Based on the modern IUPAC classiﬁcation of adsorption isotherms [39,40], all catalysts displayed type I adsorption isotherms with H4 hysteresis loops. These are indicative of microporous materials with some narrow slit-like pores and mesopores as reported in previously published works [41–44]. The corresponding NLDFT pore size distributions confirmed that the majority of these pores were approximately 0.5–0.6 nm plus some mesopores larger than 2 nm, as shown in Fig. S1b. The micropore size of ZSM-5 became narrower after dealumination and Au addition. The 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F catalyst presented a high and narrow peak near 0.55 nm, indicating more regular pore channels than the other catalysts. The specific pore structure parameters of the ZSM-5-based catalysts are listed in Table 1, together with the actual Au loadings of Au-containing catalysts. ZSM-5-F maintained its original pore structure parameters but with a smaller volume of micropores. Si species most likely filled the cavities that were created by the removal of Al from the ZSM-5 framework due to AHFS hydrolysis. Furthermore, the surface area and volume of the micropores of the catalysts were reduced further with a relative increase in the mesoporous area after Au loading. This suggests that some of the small Au nanoparticles entered the micropores. The formation of some additional mesopores due to Au addition could be a result of the basic environment of the catalysts’ preparation process. 3.2 Dispersion of gold nanoparticles TEM and the corresponding EDX spectroscopy were employed to further study the structural properties of Au metal particles in the Au-ZSM-5-F catalyst. Fig. 2a shows a TEM image of 0.3% Au/ZSM-5-F, in which the Au nanoparticles were unevenly distributed in size, ranging from a few nanometers to nearly 200 nm. This agrees with the XRD patterns. The shape of the Au nanoparticles varied from elliptical to irregular, with multiple nanoparticles connected. The contact pattern with ZSM-5 also varied, and some were simply deposited on the surface, while others were interspersed in the gaps or embedded in the carrier. In addition to larger Au nanoparticles, the EDX mapping analysis of Si, Al, and Au for the 0.3% Au/ZSM-5-F catalyst is shown in Fig. 2. These small Au nanoparticles that filled the pores of ZSM-5-F were likely the main reason for the reduction in the micropore size of the parent catalyst, as observed in the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms in Fig. S1. 3.3 Distribution of Si and Al Solid-state high-resolution MAS NMR provides a powerful tool to probe the zeolite framework to obtain important information about its elemental components and arrangements. 27Al MAS NMR is sensitive to differently-coordinated Al species and is therefore commonly used to monitor the extraction of Al from a framework. This process involves a transition from tetra-coordinated framework Al (50–65 ppm) to sixfold-coordinated extra-framework Al (∼ 0 ppm), through fivefold coordinated partially detached Al (∼ 38 ppm) [45,46]. Fig. 3 shows the 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the ZSM-5 catalysts before and after modification. All catalysts showed characteristic peaks of hexa-coordinated extra-framework Al and tetra-coordinated framework Al at the corresponding positions. The characteristic peak of the tetra-coordinated framework Al of ZSM-5-F at 54 ppm was slightly weaker than that of ZSM-5 due to the removal of some framework Al atoms from the zeolite by AHFS. 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F showed considerable horizontal broadening in the spectral line of the tetra-coordinated framework Al. This indicated the presence of Al species in an asymmetric environment due to the incorporation of Au and the existence of the five-coordinated extraframework aluminum species at 38 ppm [46,47]. The 27Al MAS NMR linewidth was determined by the nuclear quadrupole coupling constant and the asymmetry factor. Since the 27Al peak width is very sensitive to the symmetry of the 27Al nucleus, a highly asymmetric environment may cause significant broadening of the spectral lines, preventing some 27Al signals from appearing [46]. Since the addition of Au was performed via the wet impregnation of the Au precursor followed by calcination, the broadening of the Al(IV) signal could be a result of the partial hydration of dehydrated ZSM-5-F based on two proposed models [40]. The fivefold-coordinated aluminum species could be formed after hydration by attaching three water oxygen atoms to the aluminum atom. These originated from SiOAlOH on a framework defect connecting to the framework via the SiOAl bridge or an Al2O3 molecule that was unconnected to the framework. High-Si zeolites have narrower spectral lines due to their lower Al content and much weaker Si-Al dipole effect; therefore, only Si (4Si,0Al) and smaller amounts of Si (3Si,1Al) appeared in the spectra [48]. As shown in Fig. S2, the 29Si MAS NMR spectra of the ZSM-5 catalysts before and after modification were fitted with Gaussian split peaks, which allowed their Si coordination to be classified. According to the equation of Si: AlFr = ∑ISi(nAl) / ∑ 0.25nISi(nAl), the framework Si to Al ratio (Si: AlFr) was calculated to be 18.7 for ZSM-5 zeolite, 20.7 for ZSM-5-F, and 21.6 for 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F. These indicate that slight delamination occurred for the two modified catalysts, ZSM-5-F and 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F. This is in agreement with the above 27Al MAS NMR analysis. When the two Al atoms in the ZSM-5 pore were sufficiently close in spatial distance, the negative charge generated by AlO4 - balanced the two positive charges carried by Co2+, allowing Co2+ to stabilize in the framework cation position [16,49]. The exchange capacity of Co2+ and equations [3] and [4] in Section 2.1.4 can therefore be used to calculate the content of “close” Al and “single” Al atoms in ZSM-5. Table 2 lists the chemical composition of all zeolite catalysts, which shows th at ZSM-5 had a “close” Al concentration of 0.084 mmol/g. The “close” Al concentration in ZSM-5-F decreased significantly after AHFS treatment, indicating obvious zeolite delamination. Furthermore, the “single” Al concentration in ZSM-5-F increased from 0.333 mmol/g to 0.386 mmol/g, consistent with the Si/AlFr data (Table 2) obtained from both ICP-OES and 29Si MAS NMR measurements. In addition, further adding trace amounts of Au had nearly no effect on the chemical composition of the zeolite. It is thus clear that the conversion of “close” Al to “single” Al can be achieved by adding a suitable AHFS without largely changing the Si: AlFr ratio. 3.4 Acidity of the modified catalysts The aluminum atoms in different T-sites of ZSM-5 resulted in various proton energies, which corresponded to acid strength [50,51]. NH3-TPD was carried out to monitor the acid strength and the number of acid sites for the studied ZSM-5-based catalysts before and after treatment ( Fig. 4). All catalysts displayed three ammonia desorption peaks: weak acidic sites at 120 °C, medium acidic sites at 215 °C, and strong acidic sites at 440 °C. Post-treatment shifted the peak positions of the acidic sites to higher temperatures with a more pronounced shift for the strong acidic sites. A similar amount of total acid sites (0.19–0.24 mmol/g acid sites) was obtained with all zeolite samples based on the spectra, while the parent ZSM-5 had the lowest value of 0.19 mmol/g acid sites. The ZSM-5 consists of alumina tetrahedra (AlO4) and silica tetrahedra (SiO4), with most AlO4 connected to SiO4 by a bridging hydroxyl group (Si-OH-Al), which acted as a Brønsted acid site [52]. Lewis acid sites are generally formed by non-framework aluminum species generated by the dealumination of the zeolite framework or by tri-coordinated unsaturated aluminum species on the framework [53]. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy can distinguish between Brønsted and Lewis acids of zeolite catalysts and is generally used to quantitatively determine the solid acid content. The determination of the acid content on solid surfaces by infrared spectroscopy is based on the absorbance per unit weight of a sample or the characteristic peak areas of Brønsted acidic sites at 1440 cm−1 and Lewis acidic sites near 1540 cm−1 per unit weight of a sample [54]. In this work, the combination of quartz-spring gravimetric adsorption and infrared spectroscopy, instead of infrared spectroscopy alone, was adopted to more precisely determine the concentration of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the catalysts [36,37]. Fig. S3 exhibits the Py-IR spectra of the catalysts at degassing temperatures of 160 and 350 °C. The spectra provide information about the concentration distribution of total acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively. Specific information about the concentrations of total acid sites and strong acid sites of the studied catalysts is presented in Table 3. In the studied samples, most acid sites were strong acids. For ZSM-5-F, the concentration of total acid sites increased upon increasing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites compared with the parent ZSM-5. However, the concentration of strong Brønsted acid sites increased considerably with a moderate increase in the number of weak Lewis acid sites. This is in agreement with the observations of S. Schallmoser et al. in their study of the local environment of Brønsted acid sites in ZSM-5 on the catalytic activity in n-pentane cracking, in which AHFS treatment was performed [32]. Notably, after adding Au species, both strong and weak Brønsted acids enhanced significantly, whereas both strong and weak Lewis acids decreased substantially. As a result, the ratio of Lewis acid sites to Brønsted acid sites (L: B) and the ratio of strong Lewis acid sites to strong Brønsted acid sites (SL: SB) decreased sharply. These results are in agreement with the 27Al NMR analysis in Section 3.3. 3.5 Catalytic cracking Dealumination is an important process that can be used to adjust the Si: Al ratio of zeolites and gives rise to their acidity and catalytic properties. Fig. 5 shows the n-octane conversion and propylene selectivity of the ZSM-5 series catalysts at different temperatures. ZSM-5-F almost completely converted n-octane at all tested temperatures, and the improved propylene selectivity increased upon increasing the reaction temperature. The addition of trace amounts of Au clearly improved the catalytic effect, and 100% n-octane conversion and improved propylene selectivity were obtained over all Au/ZSM-5-F catalysts. 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F exhibited the highest propylene selectivity among all catalysts, with a propylene selectivity at least 20% higher than those of ZSM-5 at all temperatures. The performance of the 0.3% Au/ZSM-5-F catalyst at 260 °C (n-octane conv.: 100%, propylene sel.: 45.2%) and 310 °C (n-octane conv.: 100%, propylene sel.: 53.2%) was similar to those of the parent ZSM-5 at 410 °C and 460 °C, respectively, which provides significant energy savings by lowering the temperature by 150 °C. This demonstrates one of the great features of Au-based catalysts, i.e., good catalytic performance under mild conditions. Furthermore, Table S1 provides a comparison of the octane cracking results with the literatures [24,55–66]. Nearly no catalyst has been tested at such low temperatures, and none of the catalysts presented 100% conversion of n-octane with a propylene selectivity greater than 60%. In addition, the recyclability test results of the studied catalysts at 360 °C are shown in Fig. 6 . The n-octane conversion and propylene yield both fluctuated within a certain range, with no significant reduction after fifteen cycles. The modified catalyst still exhibited superior catalytic performance compared with the parent ZSM-5, indicating that the studied catalysts have good stability. ( Fig. 7). 4 Discussion To further clarify the role of gold particles in producing propylene via catalytic cracking over Au-modified ZSM-5 catalysts, the product distributions of n-octane catalytic cracking over three catalysts of the parent ZSM-5, ZSM-5-F, and 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F at 260 °C, 360 °C, and 460 °C were collected and shown in Table 4. The typical products of both monomolecular and bimolecular cracking were obtained, in agreement with previous results [53,66,67]. Products including ethylene, propylene, butene, isobutane, and n-butane were accompanied by the formation of very small amounts of aromatics, and trace amounts of methane, ethane, and propane. The data listed in Table 4 do not include the amounts of methane, ethane, or propane. One can see that propylene, the main product, increased gradually with the reaction temperature, while butene, isobutane, and n-butane gradually decreased. The selectivity of ethylene at 260 °C and 360 °C was relatively poor for the three catalysts, while a sharp increase at 460 °C occurred with an obvious decrease in C4 products. At lower reaction temperatures (≤ 360 °C), there were mainly (> 90%) two kinds of final products, i.e., C3 (C3 =) and C4 (C4 =, i-C4 0, and n-C4 0). According to the definition of the cracking mechanism ratio (CMR) as ‘‘(C1 + C2)/i-C4” that is directly proportional to the ratio of monomolecular to the bimolecular mechanism proposed by Wielers et al. [68], it can be concluded that bimolecular cracking was dominant in our studied system, especially at temperatures ≤ 360 °C. This result is in line with the conclusions of published work [68,69]. The classical bimolecular carbenium-ion chain mechanism, which involves a hydride-transfer step followed by isomerization and β-scission, is favored by low reaction temperatures. The significant increase in the formation of ethene, one of the main representative n-alkane monomolecular cracking products at 460 °C, implies that the monomolecular cracking of n-octane made a greater contribution at higher temperatures [70], in addition to the contribution of thermal cracking. Compared with the performance of the parent ZSM-5, the conversion of n-octane at 260 °C over ZSM-5-F was considerably higher, along with an obvious increase in C4 products and a negligible decrease in the propylene selectivity. This implies that the transformation of “close” Al to “single” Al promoted cleavage of the central C-C bonds of n-alkanes and was attributed to an increase in the strong Brønsted acid sites after AHFS treatment in the presence of a buffer, as observed by our Py-IR measurements (Fig. S3 and Table 3). For the Brønsted acid-catalyzed cracking of straight-chain paraffins, if initiation occurs via carbonium ions, the central C-C bonds are most attractive to the Brønsted proton [71]. When the temperature increased to 360 °C for ZSM-5-F, the propylene selectivity increased, and the n-butane selectivity decreased, with a constant selectivity to isobutane and butene compared with the parent ZSM-5 catalyst at the same reaction temperature. The secondary cracking of n-butane via classical β-scission might have occurred simultaneously. The results unequivocally show that the presence of non-framework aluminum is associated with an enhancement in the cracking activity, which might be caused by the interaction of non-framework aluminum with nearby Brønsted acid sites, which enhanced the strength of Brønsted acids [32,72]. Both non-framework Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites nearby may mutually act as the active sites for the bimolecular mechanism, in agreement with the conclusion proposed by Wielers et al. [68]. After adding 0.3 wt% gold into the ZSM-F sample, very different results to those of ZSM-F were obtained. The propylene selectivity was considerably enhanced from 30.6% to 44.4% with a continued increase in the n-octane conversion from 99% to 100%. The formation of i-butane was more pronounced, accompanied by a significantly lower n-butane yield and a moderate decrease in the butene yield. The Py-IR results in Table 3 show that both strong and weak Brønsted acid sites were significantly enhanced, while there was a substantial decrease in both strong and weak Lewis acid sites after introducing Au species into the ZSM-5-F substrate. The N2 adsorption-desorption measurements showed that the pore size of ZSM-5-F became narrower (Fig. S1 and Table 1) after adding Au. The increase in Brønsted acid sites and the optimization of pore structure after loading Au were responsible for the improved Py selectivity and n-octane conversion [73]. However, thinking about the different product distributions between 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F and ZSM-5-F, the role of Au species in the reaction is still unclear. The isomerization of n-butane on Au/ZSM-5 below 400 °C was once reported by Aisha et al., and Au+ species were considered to play an important role except for the acid sites [74]. The analysis of Au/ZSM-5-F via UV-Vis (Fig. 7), H2-TPR, and XPS (Fig. S4) indicated the reduction of Au3+ into metallic Au. Some Au+ species still existed in the final catalyst. Corma et al. found that the dehydrogenation of an alkane formed an olefin and initiated (or at least enhanced) the cracking reaction [75]. To determine if nanogold showed similar activity in dehydrogenation to other metals, such as Pt, Pd, Ag, and Fe [76–80], we carried out ethane dehydrogenation over the studied catalysts by using the feed of 1 vol% ethane in nitrogen with a velocity of 6 mL/g‧h. The results are presented in Table S2. At 260 °C, ethene was observed only over the catalyst containing Au. This result suggests that improvements in n-octane catalytic cracking after Au addition partially resulted from the dehydrogenation of gold species. Au-based catalysts have been used for ethanol [81] and benzyl alcohol dehydrogenation [82] at low temperatures. As shown in Fig. 8, a comparison was made between the inert support of silicate-1 and ZSM-5 and their supported Au catalysts in the reaction of n-octane cracking. Similar conversion and propylene selectivity were obtained over S-1 and Au/S-1. Thinking about the clear improvement in the performance after Au loaded on ZSM-5, there appears to be synergy between acid sites and Au species in the catalytic cracking reaction over bi-functional Au/ZSM-5 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9a, the XANES spectra of Au/ZSM-5 were similar to that of the Au foil, indicating the oxidation state of most Au atoms was mainly Au0, in line with the XPS analysis in Fig. S4. The corresponding EXAFS data after Fourier transform (FT) in R-space (Fig. 9b) presented two peaks around 2.5 and 3.2 Å for Au/ZSM-5. These peaks were attributed to a single Au-Au shell, and the splitting was due to Ramsauer-Townsend resonance [83]. No features of Au-Si or Au-Al bonds were found, but the clear enhancement of Au 5d/6 s DOSs indicates electron transfer from Au to the ZSM-5 matrix. Therefore, it could be assumed that reduced Au0 and Au+ might be involved in charge transfer with neighboring framework alumina atoms, which affected the framework electronegativity of the zeolites and changed the acid strength of the Si(OH)Al group to some extent. This has been discussed in other works [84–86] concerning the nature of metal-support interactions [85] and the influence of noble metal Pt in support acidity and the strength of Brønsted acid sites due to metal-support interactions in zeolite-supported noble metal catalysts [84,86]. However, this inference needs further investigation. 5 Conclusions The microscopic acidity of ZSM-5 was modulated by AHFS to achieve the transition from “Close” Al to “Single” Al. A series of Au/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by dealumination and silicon supplementing of ZSM-5 with (NH4)2SiF6 (AHFS). They were further modified with Au(en)2Cl3 precursor, followed by calcination in air at 550 °C. The corresponding catalysts were investigated for their catalytic activities and stabilities during the catalytic cracking of n-octane in the temperature range of 260–460 °C. The observations and results led to the following conclusions: 1) AHFS-treated ZSM-5 converted ZSM-5 “Close” Al (n = 2) to “Single” Al (n > 2) while leaving the Si: AlFr ratio essentially unchanged even after adding gold species. 2) The ZSM-5-F catalyst prepared by this method led to a small increase in weak Lewis acid sites but enhanced the strength of Brønsted acids. It considerably promoted the conversion of n-octane, even at a low reaction temperature of 260 °C, and further increased the propylene selectivity at higher temperatures. 3) The addition of trace amounts of Au species lowered the surface area and volume of the micropores of ZSM-5-F, with 0.3%Au/ZSM-5-F being the most significant. Its pore size distribution curves showed more regular microporous channels. 4) The addition of gold species further enhanced the Brønsted acidity and reduced the Lewis acidity. 5) The addition of gold species broadened the 27Al NMR peaks, indicating the formation of a more distorted tetrahedral Al environment. 6) HRTEM observations showed many large, irregular gold particles deposited on the outer surface of ZSM-5; however, the element maps, pore size distribution curves, and 27Al NMR results suggested the presence of gold species inside ZSM-5 channels. XPS spectra indicated that the chemical state of Au in the final catalyst was metallic Au and some Au+. 7) Significantly enhanced propylene selectivity was obtained over the optimized Au-ZSM-5 catalyst with 0.3 wt% gold loading with 100% n-octane conversion over the entire tested temperature range. Au played a more positive effect in cracking, isomerization, and dehydrogenation at lower temperatures. We proposed that the electron transfer from gold species to the zeolite framework affected the zeolite framework electronegativity and changed the acid strength of the Si(OH)Al groups. This provides a useful strategy to explore the acidic nature of bifunctional zeolite catalysts and may shed light on their structure-function relationships. coredata.dc:description: With respect to catalysis, the pursuit of low reaction temperatures has received continuous efforts for developing energy efficient and environmentally friendly processes. In this study, the significant promotion in the catalytic cracking performance of n-octane at low temperatures of 260–460 °C over Au/ZSM-5 catalysts was obtained via the joint contribution of dealumination and Au species. A 63.5% propylene selectivity and 100% n-octane conversion were obtained over the optimized catalyst at 410 °C. The higher propylene yield was attributed to an increase in the concentration of Brønsted acids and a decrease in that of Lewis acids, as well as synergy between acid sites and Au species. The positive effect of Au species during dehydrogenation at lower temperatures was verified, and electron transfer from Au to the zeolite framework was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: A highly efficient bi-functional zeolite catalyst for low temperature catalytic cracking of n-octane to produce propylene: Joint contribution of nanogold and dealumination
